Introduction

Chalazion, also known as a meibomian cyst, is a common benign eyelid disorder resulting from a granulomatous reaction to obstructed meibomian glands.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



Chalazion develops when the meibomian glands, which secrete oily substances that contribute to the tear film, become blocked.  The obstruction leads to the accumulation of glandular secretions within the gland, causing inflammation and the formation of a painless, firm nodule.  Therefore, risk factors are based on etiologies that increase and thicken meibomian gland secretion, including chronic blepharitis (inflammation of the eyelid margin), rosacea, seborrheic dermatitis, and poor eyelid hygiene.

Clinical presentation



Patients typically have a firm, painless nodule on the eyelid.  The lesion may initially be small but can gradually increase in size over time.  Chalazia are more commonly located on the upper eyelid, but can occur on the lower eyelid (

image 1
).  Rarely, patients may experience mild eyelid redness or irritation.

Diagnosis



Chalazion is primarily diagnosed clinically, based on the characteristic appearance of a painless, rubbery eyelid nodule.  Examination of the eyelid using magnification may reveal a central punctum, indicating the site of glandular obstruction.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis of chalazion includes:



  • Hordeolum (stye):  is an acute, painful infection of the eyelid glands (Zeis or meibomian glands), typically caused by Staphylococcus aureus.  Unlike chalazion, hordeolum presents with localized erythema, swelling, and tenderness.  It often involves the eyelash follicles and is near the eyelid margin.
  • Dacryocystitis (
    image 2
    ):  is an infection or inflammation of the lacrimal sac caused by nasolacrimal duct obstruction.  It presents with localized swelling, erythema, and tenderness in the medial canthal region.  Unlike chalazion, dacryocystitis is associated with tearing, discharge, and expression of pus from the puncta on palpation of the lacrimal sac.
  • Molluscum contagiosum (
    image 3
    ):  typically presents as single or multiple small, dome-shaped, pearly papules with central umbilication.
  • Xanthelasma (
    image 4
    ):  are cholesterol-filled lesions that appear as yellow-orange macules, papules, or plaques on the medial surface of bilateral (rather than unilateral) eyelids.
  • Eyelid malignancies:  are a variety of malignancies affecting the eyelids, such as basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma.  These lesions may present as nonhealing ulcers, nodules, or pigmented lesions on the eyelid margin or skin.

Laboratory evaluation



Laboratory testing is generally not indicated for the diagnosis of chalazion.  However, in cases of atypical presentation, a skin biopsy may be performed to rule out systemic diseases or malignancy.

Management



Most chalazia are conservatively managed with warm compresses applied to the affected eyelid several times a day to promote glandular drainage and resolution of inflammation.  Eyelid hygiene measures, such as gentle eyelid massage and cleansing, can help prevent recurrence.  Surgical excision or steroid injections may be performed for large, persistent chalazia refractory to conservative measures or those causing visual obstruction.

Prognosis



Chalazion generally resolves spontaneously within several weeks to months with appropriate conservative management.  If chalazion is persistent, biopsy should be performed to rule out malignancy.

Summary



Chalazion is a common eyelid disorder characterized by the obstruction of meibomian glands and subsequent formation of a painless eyelid nodule.  Management is conservative with warm compresses to promote gland drainage.
